entry.title: Income Tax Depreciation for Fixed Assets in SAP S/4 HANA (India Specific)
entry.content:
Introduction: 

Income Tax Depreciation India

Depreciation under the Income Tax Act is a deduction allowed for the reduction in the real value of a tangible or intangible asset used by a taxpayer.

Depreciation is defined as a reduction in the value of the asset due to wear and tear of the asset. People claim the deduction of depreciation only for accounting or for the purpose of taxation.

Difference between Book Depreciation & Tax Depreciation.

Book depreciation can be described as the amount registered in a company‚Äôs general ledger accounts. Book depreciation is always reported on the specific company‚Äôs financial statements.

Tax depreciation is the amount specified in the company‚Äôs income tax returns. 

The major difference between book depreciation and tax depreciation is timing. It includes the timing of when the price of an asset will reflect as depreciation expenditure on the company‚Äôs financial statement against depreciation expenditure on the organization's income tax return. Therefore, the depreciation expenditure will remain different in each year. However, the total of all years‚Äô depreciation expenditure for any asset is expected to add up the same total. The organization needs to maintain depreciation records for financial statement depreciation. The organization should also need to maintain depreciation records for the tax return depreciation.

Tax depreciation is calculated for the purpose of income tax. Book depreciation is prepared in accordance with the matching concept. In other words, to prepare book depreciation the revenue and expenditures produced must be recognized and registered for a similar accounting period. The organization needs to maintain two kinds of records for depreciation namely for financial reporting purpose and income tax purposes.

Depreciation under Income Tax Act

Section 32 of the Income Tax Act 1961 talks about depreciation.

Income Tax Act of 1961 allows the depreciation of tangible assets and intangible assets. In the case of a tangible asset, we can claim the deduction against building, plant, and machinery. In the case of an intangible asset, we can claim a deduction against the patents, trademark, copyright, license, franchise or any other business or commercial right of similar nature. We can claim the deduction on depreciation on those assets which have been used by the assessee for the purpose of business or profession during the previous year.

If any asset which has been used for less than 180 days then 50% of depreciation is allowable in that year.

For Financial Year (April - March):

  • Asset which has been put to use till 2nd October, 100% depreciation will be charged
  • Asset which has been put to use after 3rd October, 50 % of depreciation rate will be charged.

Block of Assets

Depreciation is calculated on the WDV of a Block of assets. Block of assets is a group of assets falling within a class of assets comprising of:

Tangible assets, being building, machinery, plant or furniture.

Intangible assets, being know how, patents, copyrights, trade-marks, licenses, franchises or any other business or commercial rights of similar nature.

The block of assets is classified further depending on the similar use, life of the asset and nature of the asset.

Written down value method (Block wise)

Every year the book value of the asset decreases and depreciation of the asset is computed on the book value of the asset. The written down value (WDV) method is the best way to calculate the depreciation of the asset because the depreciation amount goes on decreasing with time. 

WDV under the Income Tax Act means:

Where the asset is acquired in the previous year, the actual cost of the asset shall be treated as WDV.

Where the asset is acquired in an earlier year, the WDV shall be equal to the actual cost incurred less depreciation actually allowed under the Act.

Additional depreciation under the Income Tax Act

The Income Tax Act only permits the written down value method. As per the Additional depreciation method, you can get the deduction only on those assets which have been used in the business or profession. However, an assessee can get the deduction only when assets are used in the year in which it was purchased.

If an asset has been used for less than 180 days then additional depreciation is allowed at 50% of the rate of additional depreciation.  

Who is non-eligible for the additional depreciation

Additional depreciation can not be claimed on plants and machinery which has been used outside India, before being installed in India. 

You cannot claim the deduction on those plants and machinery which have been installed in the office premises or in residential accommodation. 

Depreciation will be computed as follows:

Name of asset

Block 1

Block 2

Block 3

 

Machine ‚Äì 15%

Furniture ‚Äì 10%

Car -15%

Opening Value

0

0

0

Add- Purchases (>or = 180 days) Purchase (<180 days)

500000+40000

20000

300000

Less- Sold during the year

0

0

0

Closing value of block before depreciation

540000

20000

300000

Depreciation

78000

2000

22500

(500000*15% + 40000*15%*1/2)

(20000*10%)

(300000*15%*1/2)

Closing WDV after depreciation

462000

18000

277500

 

Configuration in SAP S/4 HANA:

  1. Business Function FIN_LOC_CI_8 should be activated in SAP. If not then activate the same. (SFW5)

  2. Depreciation Area 15 to be created. 

    Financial Accounting - Asset Accounting - General Valuation - Depreciation Area - Define Depreciation Area

    Here, area does not post should be ticket to avoid accounting entry creation, as ITD is only used for reporting and not for accounting.

  3. Add India Specific Tab added in the asset master tab specific layout, to get India specific tab activated in the Asset Master.

    Financial Accounting - Asset Accounting - Master Data - Screen Layout - Specify Tab Layout for Asset Master Record



  4. Depreciation area to be assigned to Asset class, each Asset class should be assigned to depreciation area 15, to get the ITD activated for the specific asset class.
  5. Block key field to be kept as mandatory in asset master. This is an optional step, if the business wants that the block in the asset master should be mandatory then this activity can be done.

    Financial Accounting - Asset Accounting - Master Data - Screen Layout - Define Screen Layout for Asset Master Data



  6. Asset Block Key Creation, this can be done via upload tool as well (J1INBLK).
    Financial Accounting - Asset Accounting - Master Data - Country-/Region-Specific Functions - India - Maintain Asset Block Details

 

After all the steps are done, block keys can be mapped in the master and the testing can be done.

Below are the list of t-code which is required for income tax depreciation.

S.No.T-codeDescription
1AS01  Asset Creation 
2AS02  Asset Change (Assign Block key) 
3J1INBLK Update Asset block key using excel file
4J1INBLKTOAST  Assign block to existing asset using excel file 
5J1INBLKOWDV  Assign Opening WDV to Asset block 
6J1INBLKADJST  Adjustment in Opening WDV of Asset Block 
7J1INBLKTRNS  Update asset transaction at block level 
8J1IDISPBLK  Display transaction details at Asset level 
9J1IDEPCALPOST  Income Tax Depreciation calculation report &Closing WDV Update 

The file format which SAP supports is .csv, below is the screenshot of the file format.

J1INBLK - To upload Asset block keys

J1INBLKTOAST - Assign block to existing asset using excel file 

Below is the list of manual activities which should be done on each server.

S.No.Manual (Cutover) Activities
1Asset master with block key
2Assigning opening WDV to asset block
3Adjustment of opening WDV with block key
4Update asset transaction detail at block level

SAP Menu path "ZITD - Income Tax Depreciation for Fixed Assets" can also be created via SE43 for the users ease.

Thank you for reading, and happy automating! 

 

Regards,

Tanya Srivastava

entry.title: Re: No actual line items were selected Message no. KB420
entry.content:
Even with identical selection variants and authorizations, you‚Äôll often see two different behaviors when KSB1 finds no data:

  • Production (PRD): KSB1 stops at the selection screen and issues ‚ÄúNo actual line items were selected ‚Äì Message KB420.
  • Test (QAS/DEV): KSB1 proceeds to print an empty ALV grid (no error).

This discrepancy almost always comes down to ALV‚Äêlayout and variant differences, not authorizations. Here‚Äôs what to check‚Äîand how to harmonize both systems.


ALV Layout Must Contain Document Number
SAP Note 2445603 changed KSB1 so that if your default ALV layout includes the field BELNR (Document Number), the program takes an alternate code path: it builds the grid (even if no data) and suppresses KB420. If your layout does not include BELNR, KSB1 throws KB420 immediately.

In your Test system you‚Äôre (perhaps inadvertently) using a layout with BELNR, so you get a blank grid. b) In Production, your default layout omits BELNR, so you get the KB420 error.
To fix this, Run KSB1 ‚Üí click Change Layout (the gear icon) ‚Üí Choose Layout, Select your ‚ÄúDefault‚Äù layout (or create a new one called e.g. Z_KSB1_EMPTY), in Displayed Fields, add Document Number (BELNR) and save. in Variant ‚Üí Save as Default so that this layout is tied to your selection variant. Now even in PRD, KSB1 will show an empty grid instead of KB420.

Ensure the Same Variant/Layout Transported
Double‚Äêcheck that the exact variant (with its layout assignment) you use in Test is also transported and set as default in Production:

  • In KSB1 ‚Üí Variants ‚Üí Display ‚Üí compare the layout name and settings.
  • Use transaction RSEUVARA or SE38 report RS_VARIANT_CONTENTS to list the variant contents in both systems.
  • If there‚Äôs any mismatch, re‚Äêtransport the Test variant (and its layout) to Production.

Watch Out for Personal vs. Global Variants

  • Personal (user‚Äêspecific) variants in Test can differ from the global (all users) variant in Production.
  • Even if named the same, a personal variant isn‚Äôt the same object as a global one.
  • Be sure you‚Äôre running the Global variant in both environments, or transport your personal variant to Production as a global variant.

entry.title: Introducing VORTEX - Your UI5 SFTP Viewer/Manager in SAP BTP CF
entry.content:
Introduction:

This is a SFTP Viewer/Editor built in UI5 - I named it,  VORTEX.

Why did I think that we need something like VORTEX? 

I have witnessed first hand how teams download open source tools like fileZilla and WINSCP ( which by the way despite all their open source goodness have been branded as unsafe by some organization for internal use.) to explore file servers, view or edit files.

These could be Integration developers who try to access the file servers for troubleshooting or these could be functionals who would like to view the files for auditing purpose or verification or for any other reason.

Now coming to the Why!

1) It's not okay to share credentials - sometimes common credentials with team members only for them to store it locally in the FileZilla or WinSCP repo. This introduces unacceptable risk!

2) There is no logging so as to who tried to access which file or edited what?

3) Sometimes people leave the organization but they still have your remote SFTP server cred right? Again a risk!

4) There is no trail of any kind to track unauthorized changes to a file.

5) If the team members access these SFTP servers for example from their own desktop what about the firewall? Do you request a specific firewall rule just so that a team member can access the file server from their local desktop?

6) Private Keys! Some sftp servers need a private key for authentication, like bank SFTP servers. How do you connect to them if you have to from your desktop? Do you ask for the private key from the security team? (Don't request that now, there is high chance they wont share it. They are private for a reason.)

7) Some third party SFTP servers are only accessible from whitelisted IP's, for example you may have multiple connections from SAP CI to such SFTP servers and SAP CI / CF IP's have been whitelisted by the third party.

If you have multiple SFTP servers to connect to , credential management is a nightmare and because of multiple reasons above it's sometimes not possible to have a holistic centralized and controlled access.

 

Solution:  

This is where VORTEX comes in. I wanted to learn UI5 but couldn't find anything interesting that would drive me to learn it. Then I got this idea about VORTEX. I thought why not. And here we are 1 week later.

VORTEX is a tool build using SAP BAS, UI5, which connects with SAP CI using my state of the art custom API's  which leverage Connectivity service for accessing cloud connector, data stores, JSCH sessions, leveraging existing virtual host on your cloud connector.

The architecture is pretty neat, I will add a diagram later but the app in SAP BTP CF , connects to SAP CI via a destination and SAP CI custom code does the rest.

Here is how it looks...

VORTEX will display all your SAP Integration Suite IFLOWS, and then allows you to pull SFTP connection details from these iflows, all at once , or selectively.

VORTEX then shows you the available connections with the relevant info

Connections blank at first

 

 Scanning

 After I do the "Scan All" We can see the pulled connections.

 Now you will see "Unique" connections here, I have a algorithm in place to determine the uniqueness of connections. If you have new iflows , you can just again come back to this tool and scan the new flows selectively or scan everything again. This wont edit / remove existing connections but will just add new connections in the list.

Now comes the interesting part!! Hmmm.. what If I need to connect to a SFTP server which doesn't have a filow in SAP CI??

Okay...You ask too much! Fine.... Just add a new connection manually!

VORTEX allows you to add new connections, Edit connections and Delete connections. (Delete button is on the extreme right)

 

Result!

 VORTEX will now allow you to make the connection to this SFTP server through SAP CI! But there is a condition, the credential or the private key should be already there in SAP CI Secure store / keystore for VORTEX to use. This guarantees that users DO NOT have access to any secure material.

Now comes the Fun part........Let's Connect!

Notice that connect column with a play button? That's what we use to connect to a particular connection!

And now we are connected! You can see all the files and folders and they have different icons depending on their type. 

 The navigation bar on top is full functionals, allows you to go back and forth between folders, delete folders and shows you the path too. since we are on root it shows "/"

Lets open a File? Okay

You can now see the file in a text editor that allows you to edit / save / view the file, nothing more.

If its a pdf file it opens in UI5 PDF Viewer.

 The salient Feature?

It connects to all 6 SFTP Connection types, Internet - Basic auth, Internet - Cert Auth, Cloud connector - Basic auth, Cloud connector - Cert auth, Internet - Dual and Internet - Cert auth

Everything is logged and tracked and logs can be seen in a log viewer utility. This logs each action from logging in , to reading a file content, to editing it, deleting it etc.

So..... Let me know what do you think. I am happy given this was my first UI5 product. Also The UI5 is just the tip of the iceberg. The real deal lies in the custom code I have built in SAP CI which enables this to work seamlessly and allows any I mean ANY thing even postman to read, edit files or do anything on the file servers.

entry.title: Re: Custom Task for new Hire to Complete on day 1
entry.content:
Hi @DavidSnider 

The sequential display of new hire tasks on the employee‚Äôs homepage can be achieved by leveraging custom tasks in SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding. Please note, these tasks are built on custom MDF objects and linked to your onboarding programs.

By configuring your onboarding program and business rules appropriately, you can ensure that only one onboarding task appears at a time and the next task only becomes visible after the employee completes the previous one. Employees see these tasks as to-do cards on their homepage, which guides them step-by-step through their first-day activities.

To set this up, create a custom MDF objects to define each task's content. Then add custom tasks linked to your MDFs into onboarding programs assigned to new hires. Follow up by using business rules or workflow logic to control task sequencing. Finally, set up notifications to alert the employees when new tasks are assigned to them.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Issue with Automatic Inspection plan assignment to in...
entry.content:
You‚Äôve created two inspection plans (GC 1 for Vendor 1, GC 2 for Vendor 2) and maintained QIRs for both on the MPN material‚Äîso now the system should pick the correct plan automatically. Here‚Äôs how to confirm everything is wired up and troubleshoot if it still always picks GC 1.

Step-1 - go to QI03, enter your Material + Plant + Vendor + Info Record. On the General Data tab, check that Status = 02 (Released). Only released QIRs are used in automatic determination. On the Inspection Plan tab, confirm that Group Counter and Usage = 04 (Goods Receipt) exactly match your plan.

In SPRO > Quality Management ‚Üí Quality Info Record ‚Üí Activate Quality Info Record for Usage 04. Ensure ‚ÄúInspection Plan Assignment‚Äù is active for the Usage you‚Äôre testing. If you have multiple usages, make sure Usage 04 (or your Z‚ÄìUsage) is included.

Step-2
In MIGO, post a GR for a PO item sourced from Vendor 2. Note the Material Document number and immediately run QA03 (Display Inspection Lot). On the Inspection Lot header, check Inspection Plan ‚Üí Group Counter. If you see GC 2, it‚Äôs working correctly. If you still see GC 1, proceed to Step 3.

Step-3
By default SAP uses this sequence when selecting a plan (SPRO path):

  • Quality Info Record (Material + Vendor + Plant + Usage)
  • Task List Group (from material master) + Usage + Plant
  • Plan with highest status and lowest group counter

To confirm your lot hit the QIR step, in QA02 go to Environment ‚Üí Inspection Lot ‚Üí Plan Assignment Trace (or use transaction QPM9), review which branch of the logic found the plan.

entry.title: Re: Output Parameter Determination for production order.
entry.content:
Even though you‚Äôve defined 11 output items under one Output Type, the Output Parameter Determination (OPD) framework will only ever return the first matching condition record‚Äîso if your condition table doesn‚Äôt differentiate by output item, every invocation picks the same form template.

How OPD picks your Form is you trigger one Output Type (e.g. PP01‚ÄìPRD_O). OPD reads the Procedure assigned to that type (e.g. 0001). It loops through the Condition Tables in your access sequence, stopping at the first record whose key fields all match your order/header data. That record carries your Print Program + Form Template, which is then called‚Äîonce for each output item you‚Äôve defined.
If every condition record is keyed only on fields like Plant, Order Type, Medium, Language, etc., then the very first record will match & supply the same form name for items 1‚Äì11.

You must extend your OPD ‚Äúform determination‚Äù condition table so you can make separate records for each output item.

Add the Output Item to the Condition Table via SPRO ‚Üí SAP S/4HANA ‚Üí Output Management ‚Üí Define Condition Tables. Copy the standard table (e.g. 800 ‚Äì PP Output) to a Z-table (e.g. Z800). In your custom Z-table, include the field Output Item (T180‚ÄìZIPOS).

Include your Z-Table in the Access Sequence via SPRO ‚Üí Output Management ‚Üí Define Access Sequences. Edit your existing sequence (used by your Procedure 0001), and insert Z800 high in the search order.

Maintain One Condition Record per Output Item via Fiori or OMOD transaction ‚Üí Manage Output Parameter Determination ‚Üí select Application: PP ‚Üí Procedure: 0001 ‚Üí Condition Records. Create 11 entries, each keyed by your usual fields + the Output Item

  • Item 1 ‚Üí Form Template = Z_MAT_REQ_SLIP
  • Item 2 ‚Üí Form Template = Z_JOB_CARD
  • ‚Ä¶
  • Item 11 ‚Üí Form Template = Z_PRT_SLIP

Because Output Item is now part of the key, OPD will match each of your 11 records exactly once, returning the correct form name for each item number.

entry.title: Re: Drilldown reports and Statitical indicator
entry.content:
When you switch on the ‚Äúactive statistical indicator‚Äù flag for certain commitment line items, you‚Äôre telling the Budget Control System (BCS) to ignore them during the budget-availability check. However, the drilldown reports in classic FM/BCS use a different data‚Äêretrieval path that does not automatically filter out statistical-indicator lines. As a result, those items still:

  • Appear in your drilldown detail
  • Are summed into the ‚ÄúCommitted‚Äù bucket
  • Reduce your displayed available budget

How Drilldown Reporting works

  • Drilldown reports read line items from the classic FM tables (FMIOI / FMIV), keyed by commitment-item, fund, cost center, etc.
  • They pull all records with a matching value type and period‚Äî‚Äãregardless of the STATISTICAL‚ÄêINDICATOR flag (STKI).
  • The ‚ÄúAvailable Budget‚Äù they calculate = Budget ‚Äì (Sum of all fetched commitments)
  • Because statistical lines are still in the tables, they end up in that ‚ÄúSum of commitments‚Äù and drive down availability.

Ways to Exclude Statistical Lines from Your Drilldown

  • In the drilldown‚Äôs selection screen, add a criterion, Statistical Indicator = Blank (exclude ‚ÄúX‚Äù). Save it as your default variant so every run skips those lines.
  • Implement the BAdI FMODK_RO_BEHAV (or the corresponding enhancement for your release). In its GET_DATA or FILTER method, drop any record where FMIOI-STKI = 'X'.

entry.title: Re: Format Date in document generation
entry.content:
Hi @Jijeesh_PG 

Thank you for your question

Unfortunately, SAP SuccessFactors capabilities do not directly provide the option to custom date formatting with month names inside Document Generation via business rules.

Here are a few things you should know and should consider

Note that SAP SuccessFactors Document Generation formats date fields based on the language and locale settings of your document template design and that controls the default date format you see.

Also, ther is currently no business rule function that dynamically converts any date field into a text string with month names. The standard month Name function returns only the current month's name but not for passed-in dates.

You can achieve your desired date format by ensuring your document template is created or copied using the language locale that formats dates as 1 January 2020.

If you require date formatting from specific date fields dynamically, you can work around this by preparing a separate text field containing the formatted date string and then map that text field into your document template. Please note that this might possibly be from an external integration or preprocessing step.

Alternatively, you have the possibility to create multiple language versions of the template for different locales and select the appropriate locale at the document generation time.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Output Parameter Determination for production order.
entry.content:
In the public-cloud edition you don‚Äôt use SPRO transactions ‚Äì all Output Parameter Determination (OPD) setup is done through Key-User Fiori apps. Here‚Äôs how you bring Output Item into your OPD logic and maintain one condition record per item:

In your Fiori Launchpad, search for and open Manage Your Solution. Click Configure Your Solution ‚Üí Implementation Guide. In the Implementation Guide (IMG) search bar, enter ‚Äúoutput parameter determination‚Äù to filter the nodes.

Under Output Management ‚Üí Output Parameter Determination select Define Condition Tables. You‚Äôll see the standard table (e.g. 800 for PP outputs). Click Copy and give your new Z-table a name (e.g. Z800). Edit Z800 and add the field. Delivery Item / Output Item (T180-ZIPOS). Save your custom table.

Back in the IMG path, go to Define Access Sequences. Find the access sequence used by your Procedure (e.g. 0001 for PP). Click Edit ‚Üí Insert Access ‚Üí choose your Z800 and place it above the standard tables.

Launch the Manage Output Parameter Determination app from your Fiori Launchpad. Filter by Application = PP and Procedure = your procedure (e.g. 0001)

Go to Condition Records ‚Üí New.

For Access 1 (or whichever you choose):

Enter your usual keys (Plant, Order Type, Output Type, Medium, Language)
Plus the Output Item (1 through 11)
Assign each a unique Form Template (Z_MAT_REQ_SLIP, Z_JOB_CARD, ‚Ä¶ Z_PRT_SLIP).

Save all 11 records

entry.title: SAP MDG: Making CR Descriptions Auto-Populated and Read-Only
entry.content:
HI SCN Folks, 

Hope you guys are doing great üôÇ

Introduction

In SAP Master Data Governance (MDG), whenever you create, change, or extend master data such as Customer, Supplier, or Material, you start by choosing a Change Request (CR) Type. Once the CR Type is selected, the system opens the Change Request screen, where the Description field is mandatory and must be filled in manually.

While this works, it often leads to inconsistent naming conventions, typos, or missing context‚Äîespecially in large teams. A better approach is to automatically populate the CR Description based on the CR Type and Data Model and make it read-only so that users can‚Äôt change it. This ensures standardization, saves time, and reduces errors.

Why Automate the CR Description?

  • Consistency: Every CR of the same type follows the same naming convention.

  • Efficiency: Users don‚Äôt waste time typing repetitive descriptions.

  • Accuracy: Eliminates human errors such as spelling mistakes or incomplete descriptions.

  • Governance: Locks the field to ensure compliance with naming rules.

The Requirement

We want the system to:

  1. Detect the CR Type and Data Model when a CR is created.

  2. Automatically fill in the Description based on these values.

  3. Make the field read-only so it cannot be manually edited.

Example:

CR Type Data Model Auto Description
ZMAT01MM"Material Creation Request"
ZCUST01BP"Customer Creation Request"
ZSUPP02BP"Supplier Extension Request"

Technical Implementation

We will achieve this using the BAdI USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGRATION.

1Ô∏è‚É£Create a BAdI Implementation

  • Go to transaction SE18 or SE19.

  • Create an implementation for the BAdI USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGRATION.

  • Choose the filter values for the relevant Data Model (e.g., BP, MM).

2Ô∏è‚É£Method to Auto-Populate the Description

Method:
IF_EX_USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGR~GET_CREQUEST_ATTRIBUTES

In this method, we will:

  • Read the Data Model (iv_model)

  • Read the CR Type (iv_crequest_type)

  • Set the Description (cv_description) accordingly

Sample Code:

METHOD if_ex_usmd_crequest_integr~get_crequest_attributes.

  IF iv_model = 'BP' AND iv_crequest_type = 'ZMDGCUS01'.
    cv_description = 'Create Customer'.   
                            
  ELSEIF iv_model = 'BP' AND iv_crequest_type = 'ZMDGSUP02'.
    cv_description = 'Change Supplier'.

  ELSEIF iv_model = 'MM' AND iv_crequest_type = 'ZMDGMAT03'.
    cv_description = 'Extend Material'.

  ENDIF.

ENDMETHOD.

 

3Ô∏è‚É£Method to Make the Field Read-Only

Method:
IF_EX_USMD_CREQUEST_INTEGR~GET_CREQUEST_FLD_PROP

Here, we change the field property so the Description field becomes Read-Only.

 Sample Code:

METHOD if_ex_usmd_crequest_integr~get_crequest_fld_prop.

  IF iv_model = 'BP' OR iv_model = 'MM'.
    cv_description_fld_prop = 'R'.  "R = Read-Only
  ENDIF.

ENDMETHOD.

 

4Ô∏è‚É£Transport & Test

  • Create a new CR for each CR Type & Data Model combination.

  • Verify that:

    • The Description is automatically filled.

    • The Description field is read-only.

After implementing the BAdI logic, we tested the functionality in SAP MDG to confirm that:

  1. The Description field is auto-populated based on the CR Type and Data Model.

  2. The Description field is read-only and cannot be manually edited.


Test Case Example

Scenario:

  • Data Model: BP

  • Change Request Type: ZMDGCUS01 (Customer Creation Request)

Expected Result:

  • Description auto-fills as "Customer Creation Request"

  • Field is non-editable

Actual Result: ‚úÖ Working as expected

Screenshots from Testing

Before 

  • Description field is empty and requires manual entry

  • Field is editable

After

  • Description automatically filled with: Customer Creation Request

  • Field is locked (read-only)

Here‚Äôs your Before vs After comparison image. This will clearly show the difference after implementing.

 

Key Observations

  • Auto-filling eliminates manual typing errors

  • Read-only property ensures naming consistency

  • Enhancement works across different CR Types and Data Models defined in the BAdI logic

 

Conclusion

With just one BAdI implementation, you can make your SAP MDG CR descriptions consistent, accurate, and locked‚Äîimproving user experience and enforcing governance standards. This small change saves time, avoids errors, and ensures that every CR is clearly described from the moment it‚Äôs created.

SAP Master Data Governance 


Thank You, 
Sandeep Suggu.
SAP Community Profile | SAP Profile | LinkedIn

entry.title: Re: Setting Default Values in Create-Dialog
entry.content:
Hi Max,

You can remove fields using Adapt UI configuration, so don't need an Adaptation Project for it. If your default values are static, you can do them in Adapt UI as well, but if values are dynamic (ie. depend on certain conditions) then you need to create an Adaptation Project in BAS and add your logic in the controller extension.

I find that if I can do everything in Adap UI then I don't create an Adaptation Project, since I don't need it. But if there is at least one thing that I need Adaptation Project for, then I do everything in the project and not use Adapt UI at all.

Hope this helps.

entry.title: Re: Adding new field(select-option) to VL10 report
entry.content:
I know this is a really old topic, but since I had a similar requirement and difficulties to find a good "How-To" which will not require me to modify SAP standard, I will share a quick guide for anyone who might find himself here in the future.

Prerequisites:

I needed to register following objects:

  • RTR3 TABL SHP_VL10_ITEM (Item-Structure for ALV data) 
  • R3TR TABL /ISDFPS/SHP_VL10_SELECT_OPTION (Needed for the custom SELECT-OPTIONS append) 
  • R3TR FUGR V50R_VIEW (UserExits)
  • R3TR PROG V50R_USEREXIT_TRANSF (Introducing the custom SELECT-OPTIONS to the standard structure) 

I created following data elements:

  • Structure: ZSHP_<CUSTOM_FIELD>_RANGE (Ranges-Table Structure for SELECT-OPTIONS)
  • Tabletype: ZSHP_<CUSTOM_FIELD>_RANGE_T (Ranges-Table with linetype ZSHP_<CUSTOM_FIELD>_RANGE)

The ranges structure should follow this template: 

SIGN Type SIGN CHAR 1 0 prefix
OPTION Type OPTION CHAR 2 0 option for range tables
LOW Type <data_element_required> <corresponding data type> <description>
HIGH Type <data_element_required> <corresponding data type> <description>

I changed following structures: 

  • SHP_VL10_SELECT_OPTIONS (Introduced a new field Z_<CUSTOM_FIELD> TYPE ZSHP_<CUSTOM_FIELD>_RANGE_T for the custom SELECT-OPTIONS)
  • SHP_VL10_ITEM (Appended a new structure e.g. ZNEWDATA with one component ZZ_<CUSTOM_FIELD> TYPE <DATATYPE_OF_CUSTOM_FIELD>)

The first step was to copy the report RV50R10C to a new Z-Report, e.g. ZRV50R10C (including ZRVV50TOP, ZV50RINCL,ZV50RSEL3).

**The following steps will only be relevant if you want to access the custom report with VL10A to VL10I transactions.

Create a Z-Transaction for each VL10-Transaction using SE93 and the copy function. That's VL10X, VL10A, VL10B, VL10C, VL10D, VL10E, VL10F, VL10G, VL10H, VL10I.

Copy the function group V50R_PRE to a custom function group, e.g. Z_VL10 and copy all of the included Function Modules aswell. 

Also copy the report RVV50R10_PRESTEP to a custom one, e.g. ZRVV50R10_PRESTEP. 

In the custom function module, e.g. ZZSHP_VL10_PRESTEP change the if statement: "IF ‚Ä¶ ZRVV50R10C". 
In SE93 VL10X transaction, change report name to ZRVV50R10_PRESTEP.
In ZRVV50R10_PRESTEP change FM call to "CALL FUNCTION 'ZZSHP_VL10_PRESTEP'"

**The previous steps will only be relevant if you want to access the custom report with VL10A to VL10I transactions.
 
In ZRV50R10C add a new text-symbol containing the text for your custom subscreen tab when VL10 is called. Then add this code: S0S_TABX = TEXT-099.

In ZV50RSEL3 add the tab and the subscreen definition:

SELECTION-SCREEN TAB (30) s0s_tabx
USER-COMMAND s0s_tabx
DEFAULT SCREEN 1080.

....

SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF SCREEN 1080 AS SUBSCREEN.
SELECTION-SCREEN BEGIN OF BLOCK v50rsel_block_e WITH FRAME.
SELECT-OPTIONS: so_<custom_field> FOR <table>-<field>.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF BLOCK v50rsel_block_e.
SELECTION-SCREEN END OF SCREEN 1080.

Then, in UserExit: V50R_USEREXIT_TRANSF you have to make the custom SELECT-OPTIONS know to the standard SELECT-OPTIONS-Structure: 

cx_select_options-<name custom element from shp_vl10_select_options>[] = <custom_select_options definition name>[].

In the UserExit LV50R_VIEWG03 the values from the custom SELECT-OPTIONS can be checked and data from the ALV output can be excluded:

SELECT SINGLE <field> FROM <table> WHERE <conditions> AND <field> IN @ix_SELECT_OPTIONS-<custom_select_options> INTO @CS_postab-<custom_field>
IF sy-subrc NE 0.
cf_subrc = 1.
ENDIF.

After leaving this User Exit with cf_subrc = 1 it will be CHECKED afterwards and data will not be appended to the ALV output table. The cs_postab field corresponds with the name you have given in your SHP_VL10_ITEM append. 

If you want to have the new field displayed in the ALV directly after running the program, I would recommend to create a default layout with your field included. Maybe you can also use LV50R_VIEWG11 to a certain extend, but be aware, I think some adjustment might be overwritten, since the default user role parameters in the VL10 will be retrieved only after this UserExit and therefore potentially overwrite your custom settings here.

entry.title: SAP Enable Now ‚Äì Different Workflows for Original and Translated Objects Within the Same Workarea
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm currently working with SAP Enable Now and have encountered an issue related to workflow management within a single workarea.

Here‚Äôs the situation:

  • I‚Äôve created a QA workflow that automatically publishes content after a successful quality assurance step.

  • All content is initially created in German.

  • Later, we want to translate the existing content into other languages ‚Äì especially Simulations, where we plan to use the translation feature and re-recording functionality provided by SAP Enable Now.

For the translation process, we would like to use a separate workflow.

So far, I‚Äôve created two workflows:

  1. One for the initial content creation in German (with automatic publishing).

  2. One for translations (with a different review process).

The problem:
A workarea in Enable Now can only be assigned one workflow. However, we‚Äôd like that when an object is duplicated for translation, it would automatically follow the second (translation) workflow without needing to switch workareas manually.

My question:
Is there a way to apply different workflows within the same workarea, depending on the object type, status, or context (e.g. original vs. translation)?
Alternatively, is there a best practice for handling translation processes that require a different workflow setup while staying within the same project or workarea?

Thank you very much in advance for any advice or input!

Best regards,

Janice

SAP Enable Now

entry.title: Re: freight-cost-condition divided per position in outbou...
entry.content:
SAP‚Äôs standard header-freight logic always splits the freight (condition type ZFRE) across all line items in each billing document, using the sum of that invoice‚Äôs net values as the denominator. On a second invoice for the same order, if ZFRE still exists, the system takes that new invoice‚Äôs net‚Äêvalue sum and redistributes the freight‚Äîhence your ‚Äú10‚Äâ‚Äì‚Äâ4‚Äâ‚Äì‚Äâ2‚Äâ=‚Äâ4‚Äâ‚Ç¨‚Äù behavior.

To instead have full 10‚Äâ‚Ç¨ split pro-rata only on the first delivery/billing (and zero freight thereafter), you must inject custom logic into the pricing routine for ZFRE. Here‚Äôs how:

Option 1: Custom VOFM Calculation Routine

  • In SPRO ‚Üí Pricing ‚Üí Pricing Control ‚Üí Define Condition Types, edit ZFRE, Set Condition Class = B (Header Condition), Under Calculation assign a custom routine (e.g. 900 or ZZ1).
  • Implement your VOFM routine (Transaction V/06, choose type B routine = ZZ1)
  • Rebuild your pricing procedure or run a pricing re‚Äêdetermination on your first invoice.
  • On the first billing document, SAP will see C_VALUE = 10 and pro-rate it by each item‚Äôs net-value. Your delivered 10 + 5 = 15 ‚Ç¨ ‚Üí splits into 6.67 ‚Ç¨/3.33 ‚Ç¨.
  • On subsequent bills, the routine returns C_VALUE = 0, so no freight appears.

Option 2: BAdI-Based Pricing Exit

  • If you cannot use VOFM routines (for example, in a public-cloud extension scenario), leverage a pricing‚Äêexit BAdI instead:
    classic MV45AFZX user‚Äêexit in the pricing program
  • In your method, replicate the above logic by reading the doc number and count existing invoices, if first invoice ‚Üí set cond amount = 10, else ‚Üí cond amount = 0.

The pricing program then pro-rata splits the header condition.

entry.title: Re: Sales Order - Return VA01
entry.content:
In Brazilian‚Äêlocalized SD, the billing‚Äêdocument header field STCD1 (‚ÄúTax Number 1‚Äù) is automatically populated from the master data of the partner assigned the ‚Äúinvoice‚Äêissuer‚Äù role. In a standard outbound invoice, that‚Äôs your sold-to/payer customer (so you see the customer‚Äôs CNPJ).

However, in a sales-return credit memo, SAP treats the document more like a vendor invoice to your own company‚Äîand the ‚Äúinvoice‚Äêissuer‚Äù ends up being the company code‚Äôs BP (or the vendor BP behind it). As a result, STCD1 is picked up from your own company code‚Äôs CNPJ master parameters rather than the customer‚Äôs.

Key Configuration Areas Affecting STCD1

Partner Determination in Billing Type (OBO1 / VOV8) Check which partner function is flagged as invoice‚Äêissuer for credit-memo type ZBDE. If it‚Äôs mapped to your company‚Äôs BP or vendor BP instead of the customer‚Äôs ‚Äúpayer‚Äù partner, STCD1 comes from the wrong master.

Copy Control ‚Äì Sales to Billing (VTFL) Under Billing Type ‚Üí Header Data ‚Üí ‚ÄúTax Number from‚Äù, you choose whether STCD1 is copied from the customer (KNA1-STCD1) or from the company code‚Äôs global FI parameters. The default for returns is often ‚Äúown company.‚Äù

BP Master & CNPJ Maintenance

  • Customer BP: STCD1 holds the CNPJ entered on the Control Data tab of the customer master.
  • Company Code (Vendor) BP: Its CNPJ lives in FI Global Parameters ‚Üí Company Code ‚Üí Additional Details.

How to force the Customer‚Äôs CNPJ into STCD1 is by adjusting Partner Determination ‚Äì In SPRO ‚Üí Sales & Distribution ‚Üí Basic Functions ‚Üí Partner Determination ‚Üí Assign Partner Functions to Billing ‚Äì For your return‚Äêbilling type ZBDE, ensure the payer or sold-to partner function (the one carrying STCD1) is the customer, not your company code/vendor BP.

Copy Control Settings ‚Äì Go to SPRO ‚Üí Sales & Distribution ‚Üí Billing ‚Üí Copy Control (Order ‚Üí Billing) ‚Äì Select your return billing type ‚Üí Header Data tab ‚Üí Field ‚ÄúTax Number from‚Äù: choose Customer Master instead of Company Code.

If none of the above options are not working, then, you need to explore custom validation either via USEREXIT_FILL_VBRK_BTE (in include MV45AFZZ) or the BAdI SD_BILLING_DOCUMENT.

entry.title: AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
The AI Adapter for SAP Integration Suite is a Generative AI driven capability available exclusively on SAP Integration Suite. For the first time in SAP CI, leverage SAP AI Core‚Äôs GenAI Hub features that allow you to achieve smarter integration solutions for your business.

AICore-GenAIHub variant allows you to connect to orchestration services in SAP AI Core. This service enables the use of various generative AI models with a unified code, configuration, and deployment.

The Custom-OpenAI-REST variant of the AI adapter works with the APIs of OpenAI that allows developers to access and integrate with artificial intelligence models into their applications, enabling tasks like text generation, image creation, and more.

AI Adapter Features

The AI Adapter has the following features:

  • AI Adapter has two variants available: AICore-GenAIHub and Custom-OpenAI-REST.
  • AI Adapter supports OAuth2 Client Credential (User Credentials) and API Key alias (Secure Parameter) authentication methods for the AICore-GenAIHub and Custom-OpenAI-REST variant respectively.
  • AICore-GenAIHub employs harmonized API to allow you to use different foundation models without changing the client code.
  • You can configure orchestration to enable consumption of multiple GenAI models within a single workflow.
  • Custom-OpenAI-REST allows you to access a range of features using APIs like Chat Completions, Platform and Responses.
  • Custom-OpenAI-REST supports Basic configuration type that provides a convenient processing capability for supported versions whereas Advanced enables proficient users to perform calls with greater control while connecting to any API endpoint. 

Example Scenario : Sentiment Analysis on Customer Feedback 

In this blog post, we will demo a scenario to get you started with a basic AI Adapter operation. We query LLM to perform sentiment analysis on user feedback.

 

The following prerequisites are handy while getting started with GenAI Hub

  • To get started with Gen AI Hub, see Getting Started with GenAIHub.
  • To consume GenAI models using Orchestration, see AI Core Orchestration Consumption.

Prepare User feedback using Content Modifier

One of the first tasks we do after creating a new integration flow is to prepare contrasting user feedback to be analyzed. As you can notice, one of them speaks highly of the blog (we assume this to be a product) and other feedback is quite the opposite.

Connect to GenAI Hub using the AI Adapter

The Connection tab contains connection and authentication parameters to connect to AICore-GenAIHub.

 

Parameter

Description

Address

Specify the GenAIHub address.

Example: https://api.ai.{tenant_name}.{datacenter}.ml.hana.ondemand.com.

OAuth2 Client Credentials

Specify the name of the OAuth2 Client Credentials security artifact.

Reuse Connection

Enable to reuse the connection.

Connection Timeout(in ms)

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for the connection to be established.

Response Timeout(in ms)

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for a response message.

Prompt an LLM using AI Adapter

This example demonstrates how to prompt a large language model (LLM) to perform sentiment analysis on for user feedback text. The model is instructed to analyze the sentiment of the review and respond with just one word‚Äîeither ‚Äúpositive‚Äù or ‚Äúnegative.‚Äù Triple backticks are used to clearly highlight the review text, ensuring there's no ambiguity about what should be analyzed. The structure is intended to produce straightforward and concise sentiment assessments.

Parameter

Description

Operation

Select the operation from the dropdown.

Orchestration Deployment ID

Specify the Deployment ID for this Orchestration.

AI Resource Group

Specify the AI Resource Group configured for the specific orchestration deployment.

Request Payload Source

 

Select an option to specify the source for request payload:

  • Exchange Body allows you to specify required structure and values. 
  • UI Configurable provides user friendly fields to create the payload automatically.

 

Model

Select the required AI model for your operation.

 

Role

Specify the role to be assumed:

  • assistant
  • system
  • user

Input

Specify the content containing the instruction to be carried out.

Run and Verify Output

After saving the above configuration, deploy the flow and verify that the sentiment has been correctly analyzed.

You should be able to see some of them as shown below:

 

Quick Links

For detailed information about AI configuration, see AI Adapter and AI Adapter Guide.

Note: The AI adapter is available as part of your SAP Integration Suite license.
